Competitive beard growing, the 1954-55 equivalent of
such famous collegiate fads as goldfish swallowing and flagpole sitting, will make its debut on the Homewood campus
on Friday, Feb. 25, 1955, the date scheduled for the judging
of the News-Letter's first Beard Growing Contest.
Remington Electric shavers will be awarded to the
three Hopkins men adjudged to possess the finest beards.
Judging will not be on the basis of'length or growing time
but on •a point-score evaluation encompassing such charactertics as color, texture, shape, "yankability," luster, over-all .appearance, and so forth.
Shaving Race
Immediately after the three winners of the shavers are
determined, they will be asked to participate in a shaving
race, using their newly-won Remingtons.
The winner of the shaving race will be awarded an elabo- Three;namely Dr. Albert L. Hammond (philosophy), Dr. Chester

On January 16th at 2:00
p.m.,
Alpha Phi Omega, the National
Service Fraternity, will initiate
twelve pledges who have satisfactorily
completed
their
three
Months pledge period.
Those being initiated are: Bobert Athey, Merrill Berman, Lloyd
Collins, Jr., Robert Dorfman,
Richard Hu and Herbert Layton.
Also Leonard Miller, Peter McNamara, Gordon Richardson,
Philip Rierson, Lincoln Simon and
William Willis.
The next pledge class will he
organized in February, 1955. It
-will include pledges from the previous class who did not satisfactorily complete their pledging and
liew applicants.
Students interested in pledging
are asked to contact Charles Burton Box 2316.

First off, we think it's good for
the spirit to foreswear some
accustomed activity at the turn
of the year. Like swearing off
drinking (until the next party)
—or giving up dates (at least,
while you're broke). But why
give up pleasant things when
you can give up a real chore
like shaving?

••••

•-•

••••

Just think! A rest for your battle-scarred chin. No more nicks
and cuts. 10 to
15 extra minutes a morning
for sleep. And
a chance to
pocket the cost of blades, shaving cream, etc., etc....

win a brand-new
Remington 60 Deluxe Shaver.
Then you'll really be in luck,
because all these benefits will
continue to be yours for years
of happy shaving. For this mansize Remington will spare you
all the trials and tribulations of
shaving.

It's so gentle it can give you a
smooth shave, even if your
beard is as soft as peach fuzz.
Yet it's so rugged it can mow
down whiskers as stiff and
tough as a brush. And it's so
powerful it can plow through
your 2-month-old Contest beard
in less than 5 minutes!

We hope you'll take our advice
and start growing your beard
tomorrow. And we hope it will
be handsome enough to win a
new Remington 60 Deluxe. But
if it isn't, and you want the
clean good looks of a supersmooth shave without the discomfort of shaving, we hope
you'll go to a Remington Shaver
dealer, or our local office, and
ask for a Remington on our 14Day Free Trial.
On second thought maybe you'd
better not. You'll probably
never want to part with it again.

A petition addressed to Senator
Butler (R., Md.) demanding the
censure of Senator McCarthy has
been circulated around campus in
the past two weeks. Between two
and three hundred signatures, including those of several faculty
members, were amassed on the
petition.
The petition was drawn up by
Yank Samberg, who did so independently of any campus organization. Most of the students who
signed did so without reading the

PRO PRO MUSICA
The Editors:
Re: Correspondence Column,
December 10.
To: My bewildered feline friend:
"Pussy cat, pussy cat, where
have you been?" I thought that
any informed person or intelligent
cat being exposed to the ideas of
Nietzsche, Schopenhauer, a n d
Wagner for the past fifty years
would have by now known what a
Straussian world-puzzle was.
But it would seem our pussycat has been lion down on the job.
Instead of reading, he writes.
I recommend he take the blinders
off his green eyes, take Nietzsche's
"Also Sprach Zarathustra" in paw

Delbert N.De Young received a B.S.in Chem.Eng.from the University
of Wisconsin last June. Now he is working for an M.S. degree. By asking
questions, he's learned that many excellent industrial opportunities are
passed over because they're not understood by the average undergraduate.

Clarence "Ding"bell answers:

Well, if I said "All sorts," it might sound a bit vague to
you, Del, but it would be very close to the truth. That's
because technical sales work at Du Pont—bearing in
mind the great diversity of products we have—is broader
in scope than a lot of other technical assignments, and
requires additional talents.
Let's suppose that one of Du Pont's customers is
having technical difficulties—needs help in adapting
"Teflon" to a specific gasketing application, for example. When our sales representative calls, he naturally
must carry with him the engineering knowledge that's
the basis for sound technical advice—data on flexural

man is going to be truly effective in such a situation, he
must possess certain human qualities in addition to his
technical ability. That is, he must really like people and
be sincerely interested in helping them solve their problems. He must—in every sense of the word—be an
"ambassador" who can handle human relationships
smoothly and effectively.
Take the depth suggested by this simple example.
Del, and multiply it by a breadth representing all the
challenging problems you'll run into with Du Pont's
diversity of products. If your slide rule isn't too far out
of alignment, the resulting area should give you some
idea of what I meant by "all sorts" of work.
Let me emphasize one more point. The importance of
effective sales work is fully understood and appreciated
at Du Pont! In the past, sales work has been one of the
active roads to top management jobs. There is every
reason to believe that this will_ continue in the future.

By BOB PARTRIDGE

The largest turnout of grapplers in recent years greeted
coach Mickey Cochrane at 5 o'clock Monday at the first
varsity wrestling meeting.
•Tyventy-six men responded to the mentor's plea to come out
and support the team, which is making a comeback at Hopkins
after several years absence_from the athletic schedule. However,
the team will miss the services of Ron Armstrong, 123-pound
co-captain who helped lead the Blue Jays to their eighth MasonDixon Conference Championship last year with a win at the
annual championships held at Towson. Happily for the Jay's
chances, Lou Ruland, 130-pound co-captain who also won an
individual Mason-Dixon championship, is back

Jay Giants Go Against Dela.Goons
By HERB KAHLER
Dickinson beat Hopkins' basketball team, 73-59, Tuesday night.
Jay Yakubisin scored 18 points
for the losers.
Hopkins' hoopsteTs, with three
games under their belts, tangle
with Delaware tomorrow night at
8:45 p.m. at the JHU gym.
Little is known about Delaware
except that they have a tall and
veteran team. Last year, Delaware
defeated Hopkins, 51-39.
In the season's opener, JHU
spearheaded by Jay Yakubisin's 23
points, nipped the Garnets of
Swarthmore in the last twelve seconds, 81-79, on a lay-up by sophomore Bill Civiletti.
The strength of Swarthmore
was somewhat of a surprise to
the many Hopkins rooters because
the visitors had looked anything
but impressive in losing to - Lafayette by 39 points and to the
University of Pennsylvania by 15
points. Last Saturday night, however, they looked much improved
as they hit with great accuracy
from the charity stripe and on
field goals. In fact their average of
73 per cent from the free-throw
line is what kept them in the
game for the Blue Jays outscored
Swarthmore from the floor 62-52.
Captain Scores 24
Garnet Capthin Lee Hallberg,
led both teams with 24 points, and
until he left the game via the
personal foul route late in the second half he was getting a lot of
rebounds. His teammate Fischer
was second in the scoring column
for Swarthmore and third in the
game with 22 markers, ten on
free throws.
The Hopkins scoring parade
was led by Yakubisin with 23
points. He was followed by three
other men in double figures:
Civiletti, 20; John Newton, 14;
and Captain Ed Habermann, 13.

Tom Gibson chipped in with five.
The two glaring weaknesses of
Hopkins were rebounding and
foul shooting. Although the Jays
floored a team averaging 6'2",
they were not able to exploit their
height in the control of the backboards. The JHU shooting average
was about 30 per cent, which is
just average; but from the charity
stripe the Jays could only make
SO per cent of their shots. Out of
38 attempts they made only 19,
and this does not count the 11
bonus tosses the Blue Jays would
have had if they had made the
first shot.
Worked Ball Well
One bright spot in the Hopkins
offense was that the JHUers were
able to work the ball in for numerous shots, and as soon as they
gain their shooting eye the points
should fall in faster.
The game was a see-saw affair
with neither team able to gain
more than a six-point advantage,
and that for only a short time.
Swarthmore took a slim early
lead, but the score was tied many
times in the first half before the
Garnets put on a small spree to
take a halftime advantage of
42-37.
The second half followed the
pattern of the first, with Hopkins
leading at one spot by six points
and then Swarthmore leading by
five.
The last three minutes found
Swarthmore ahead by four points,
77-73, and attempting to freeze
the ball. But the Jays were able
to crack the stall and tie up the
game 77-77. Civiletti c a ni e
through in the dying seconds to
chip in two points and wrap up
the game for Hopkins.

over a select fraternity team, it

Ballhandling and passing was
at times rather sloppy, and many

or controlled the boards when
they shouldn't have had position.
The four-man weave arpund the
key-hole pulls the big man, Frank
Porter, in and out from center
slot .to corner and even backcourt, leaving the center free for
driving and feeding, but also
strictly limiting Porter's chances
on the offensive boards. Porter
employs a graceful hook, good
inside jumpshot and tap-in finger
tip control.

Bob Partridge, and Wilson Magruder are entered.

Competitive beard growing, the 1954-55 equivalent of
such famous collegiate fads as goldfish swallowing and flagpole sitting, will make its debut on the Homewood campus

of the News-Letter's first Beard Growing Contest.

race, using their newly-won Remingtons.

Delbert N.De Young received a B.S.in Chem.Eng.from the University
of Wisconsin last June. Now he is working for an M.S. degree. By asking
questions, he's learned that many excellent industrial opportunities are
passed over because they're not understood by the average undergraduate.

Clarence "Ding"bell answers:

Well, if I said "All sorts," it might sound a bit vague to
you, Del, but it would be very close to the truth. That's
because technical sales work at Du Pont—bearing in
mind the great diversity of products we have—is broader
in scope than a lot of other technical assignments, and
requires additional talents.
Let's suppose that one of Du Pont's customers is
having technical difficulties—needs help in adapting
"Teflon" to a specific gasketing application, for example. When our sales representative calls, he naturally
must carry with him the engineering knowledge that's
the basis for sound technical advice—data on flexural

"ambassador" who can handle human relationships
smoothly and effectively.
Take the depth suggested by this simple example.
Del, and multiply it by a breadth representing all the
challenging problems you'll run into with Du Pont's
diversity of products. If your slide rule isn't too far out
of alignment, the resulting area should give you some
idea of what I meant by "all sorts" of work.
Let me emphasize one more point. The importance of
effective sales work is fully understood and appreciated
at Du Pont! In the past, sales work has been one of the
active roads to top management jobs. There is every
reason to believe that this will_ continue in the future.

By BOB PARTRIDGE

The largest turnout of grapplers in recent years greeted
coach Mickey Cochrane at 5 o'clock Monday at the first
varsity wrestling meeting.
•Tyventy-six men responded to the mentor's plea to come out
and support the team, which is making a comeback at Hopkins
after several years absence_from the athletic schedule. However,
the team will miss the services of Ron Armstrong, 123-pound
co-captain who helped lead the Blue Jays to their eighth MasonDixon Conference Championship last year with a win at the
annual championships held at Towson. Happily for the Jay's
chances, Lou Ruland, 130-pound co-captain who also won an
individual Mason-Dixon championship, is back

By HERB KAHLER
Dickinson beat Hopkins' basketball team, 73-59, Tuesday night.
Jay Yakubisin scored 18 points
for the losers.
Hopkins' hoopsteTs, with three
games under their belts, tangle
with Delaware tomorrow night at
8:45 p.m. at the JHU gym.
Little is known about Delaware
except that they have a tall and
veteran team. Last year, Delaware
defeated Hopkins, 51-39.
In the season's opener, JHU
spearheaded by Jay Yakubisin's 23
points, nipped the Garnets of
Swarthmore in the last twelve seconds, 81-79, on a lay-up by sophomore Bill Civiletti.
The strength of Swarthmore
was somewhat of a surprise to
the many Hopkins rooters because
the visitors had looked anything
but impressive in losing to - Lafayette by 39 points and to the
University of Pennsylvania by 15
points. Last Saturday night, however, they looked much improved
as they hit with great accuracy
from the charity stripe and on
field goals. In fact their average of
73 per cent from the free-throw
line is what kept them in the
game for the Blue Jays outscored
Swarthmore from the floor 62-52.
Captain Scores 24
Garnet Capthin Lee Hallberg,
led both teams with 24 points, and
until he left the game via the
personal foul route late in the second half he was getting a lot of
rebounds. His teammate Fischer
was second in the scoring column
for Swarthmore and third in the
game with 22 markers, ten on
free throws.
The Hopkins scoring parade
was led by Yakubisin with 23
points. He was followed by three
other men in double figures:
Civiletti, 20; John Newton, 14;
and Captain Ed Habermann, 13.

beaten American University 24-8, met Western Maryland at
Towson Wednesday night.

Tom Gibson chipped in with five.
The two glaring weaknesses of
Hopkins were rebounding and
foul shooting. Although the Jays
floored a team averaging 6'2",
they were not able to exploit their
height in the control of the backboards. The JHU shooting average
was about 30 per cent, which is
just average; but from the charity
stripe the Jays could only make
SO per cent of their shots. Out of
38 attempts they made only 19,
and this does not count the 11
bonus tosses the Blue Jays would
have had if they had made the
first shot.
Worked Ball Well
One bright spot in the Hopkins
offense was that the JHUers were
able to work the ball in for numerous shots, and as soon as they
gain their shooting eye the points
should fall in faster.
The game was a see-saw affair
with neither team able to gain
more than a six-point advantage,
and that for only a short time.
Swarthmore took a slim early
lead, but the score was tied many
times in the first half before the
Garnets put on a small spree to
take a halftime advantage of
42-37.
The second half followed the
pattern of the first, with Hopkins
leading at one spot by six points
and then Swarthmore leading by
five.
The last three minutes found
Swarthmore ahead by four points,
77-73, and attempting to freeze
the ball. But the Jays were able
to crack the stall and tie up the
game 77-77. Civiletti c a ni e
through in the dying seconds to
chip in two points and wrap up
the game for Hopkins.

Sloppy Passmg, But
whip Frat All-Stars
After Tuesday's 53-45 victory
over a select fraternity team, it
is obvious that the Freshman bbailers have the material and
spirit, but still lack the needed
polish.
Ballhandling and passing was
at times rather sloppy, and many
times the fraternity men managed to get a man in on a drive,
or controlled the boards when
they shouldn't have had position.
The four-man weave arpund the
key-hole pulls the big man, Frank
Porter, in and out from center
slot .to corner and even backcourt, leaving the center free for
driving and feeding, but also
strictly limiting Porter's chances
on the offensive boards. Porter
employs a graceful hook, good
inside jumpshot and tap-in finger
tip control.

Since there are only five weight
classes in the tournament, Coach
Bob Scott says "We haven't
dropped men into specific weight
classes yet, but we are just preparing them for the intramural
meet. After the Christmas vacation they will be put into their
respective weight classes."
As things shape up now, entered
in the 167 pound class for the
meet are Dick Reilly, Jim Lory,
Carl Chatzky, George Schuppert,
and Barton Sheen. Of these five,
one and possibly two will be
shifted up to the 177 pound
class, according to Scott. in the
147 pound class, Bob Dorfman,
Bob Partridge, and Wilson Magruder are entered.
